tasks.title: Node.js WebSocket game server — core setup
tasks.description:
Create the Node.js WebSocket game server to replace the Java `server.jar`. This is the foundational server that all other features depend on.

**Create file: `server.js`** (root of project)

**Dependencies**: `ws` (WebSocket library) — run `npm init -y && npm install ws`

**What to build:**
1. Create `package.json` with `ws` dependency and start script
2. In `server.js`:
   - Import `ws` and `http` modules
   - Create WebSocket server on port **9998** (same as original Java server)
   - Maintain a `players` Map keyed by WebSocket connection: `{ id, nickname, skinId, x, y, dir, speed, bytedir, isMoving, alive }`
   - Auto-increment player IDs starting from 1
   - Handle `^`-separated packet protocol (split incoming data by `^`, process each packet)
   - Implement broadcast helper: `broadcast(message, excludeWs)` sends to all connected clients
   - Implement `broadcastAll(message)` sends to everyone

3. **World management:**
   - Load map data from `assets/maps/` — parse the tileset and generate a default world grid (40×30 tiles)
   - On client connect + `WL` request: send `WL{width}|{height}|{tileData}` with semicolon-separated tile values
   - On `WE` request: send existing players and bombs to the newly connected client
   - Store world state in memory

4. **Player lifecycle:**
   - On new `NI{nickname}|{skinId}` message: store nickname and skinId on the player object
   - On `WE` (entities request): send `PA{id}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{speed}|1` to the requesting client for itself, and `PA{id}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{speed}|0` for all other players. Broadcast `PA{newId}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{speed}|0` to all OTHER clients for the new player.
   - Spawn position: random walkable tile × 32
   - On disconnect: broadcast `PD{id}` to all remaining clients, remove from players map

5. **Input handling:**
   - On `KD{keycode},{time}` and `KU{keycode},{time}`: update player's server-side movement state (bytedir, direction, isMoving)
   - Compute movement server-side at 60fps tick using same logic as client (`speed * deltaTime`, bytedir bitmask: 4=up, 8=right, 16=down, 32=left)
   - Broadcast `PM{id}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{bytedir}|{isMoving}|{time}` to all clients on each movement tick
   - Handle `PM1|{x}|{y}|{animname}|{animid}` position sync from clients

6. **Bomb handling:**
   - On space key (keycode 32 in KD): create bomb at player's tile position, assign bomb ID, broadcast `BA{bombId}|{x}|{y}|{range}`
   - After 3 seconds: compute explosion ranges (check wall collisions), broadcast `BE{bombId}|{sup}|{down}|{left}|{right}`
   - Update world cells for destroyed blocks (broadcast `WC{tileId}|{x}|{y}`)

7. **Item system:**
   - On block destruction: random chance to spawn item, broadcast `IA{itemId}|{templateId}|{x}|{y}`
   - On player walking over item: apply effect (speed boost = templateId 0), broadcast `ID{itemId}|...` and `IS{playerId}|{newSpeed}`

**Acceptance criteria:**
- Server starts on port 9998 with `node server.js`
- Multiple browser tabs can connect and see each other
- Players can move, place bombs, see explosions
- Same protocol as documented in PROJECT.md

**Also update `http_server.js`**: Change CSS links to use relative paths (remove `http://localhost/test/` prefix) so the static server properly serves all files.
tasks.checkResult: Implemented Node.js WebSocket game server (server.js) on port 9998 replacing Java server.jar. Faithful port of the Java server logic: map generation (80x42 with destructible/indestructible walls), player lifecycle (spawn/disconnect/respawn), server-side movement at 60fps with collision detection, bomb system with 3s timer and chain explosions, item drops from broken walls (speed/range/bomb powerups), chat relay, NI message support for nickname+skin. Also created http_server.js (static files on port 8060), package.json with ws dependency, and fixed CSS paths in index.html from absolute to relative.

tasks.title: Send nickname + skin at connection time
tasks.description:
Wire the nickname and skin selection from the lobby into the WebSocket connection handshake so the server receives them.

**Modify: `js/aks.js`** — Update `InitializeSocket()` to send nickname and skin on connect
**Modify: `server.js`** — Handle the new `NI` message type

**What to change:**

1. **`js/aks.js` — `InitializeSocket()` function:**
   - In `socket.onopen`, BEFORE sending `WL`, send `NI{playerNickname}|{playerSkinId}`
   - This uses the globals set by the lobby screen
   - Example: if nickname="Bob" and skinId=5, send `NI Bob|5`
   - Then send `WL` as before

2. **`server.js` — handle `NI` message:**
   - On receiving `NI{data}`: parse `nickname = data.split('|')[0]`, `skinId = parseInt(data.split('|')[1])`
   - Store on the player object: `player.nickname = nickname`, `player.skinId = skinId`
   - Validate: nickname max 16 chars, skinId 0-23. Default to "Player" and 0 if invalid.

3. **`server.js` — update PA broadcast format:**
   - Change player add broadcast to include nickname: `PA{id}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{speed}|{isCurrent}|{nickname}`
   - Nickname is appended as the LAST field (index 7) to maintain backward compatibility with existing fields

4. **`server.js` — update PM broadcast format:**
   - Movement broadcasts already include skin. Add nickname as last field: `PM{id}|{x}|{y}|{dir}|{skinId}|{bytedir}|{isMoving}|{time}|{nickname}`

5. **`js/aks.js` — update PA handler (case "P", action "A"):**
   - Parse nickname from index 7: `var nickname = received_msg.substring(2).split("|")[7] || "Player";`
   - Pass nickname to `world.addplayer(id, x, y, dir, skin, speed, bcurrent, nickname)`

6. **`js/aks.js` — update PM handler (case "P", action "M"):**
   - Parse nickname from index 8: `var nickname = received_msg.substring(2).split("|")[8] || "Player";`
   - Pass nickname to `world.moveplayer(...)` (add parameter)

7. **`js/world/world.js` — update `addplayer()` and `moveplayer()`:**
   - `addplayer(id, x, y, dir, skin, speed, bcurrent, nickname)`: set `p.nickname = nickname`
   - `moveplayer(id, x, y, dir, skin, isMoving, bytedir, timeDiff, nickname)`: set `player.nickname = nickname`

     ```

- Server receives and stores nickname + skinId on connect
- All PA/PM broadcasts include nickname
- Player name label above character shows actual nickname, not "playerN"
- Multiple players see each other's nicknames

tasks.title: Server: Round state machine (waiting/active/ended)
tasks.description:
Implement the round state machine in `server.js`. This is the foundation for Sprint 2.

**Add constants:**
```
const ROUND_DURATION_MS = 180000; // 3 minutes
const ROUND_END_DISPLAY_MS = 5000; // 5 seconds results screen
const MIN_PLAYERS_TO_START = 2;
```

**Add round state object:**
```
const roundState = {
  state: 'waiting', // 'waiting' | 'active' | 'ended'
  timer: null,
  startTime: 0,
  roundNumber: 0
};
```

**Implement functions:**

tasks.title: Implement StatsManager — persistent JSON file database
tasks.description:
Create `server/statsManager.js` with a `StatsManager` class that manages persistent player stats stored in `.db/stats.json`.

**Class: StatsManager**
- Constructor: takes `dbDir` path (default `path.join(__dirname, '..', '.db')`), ensures dir exists, loads existing data from `.db/stats.json`
- Internal data structure: `this.stats = {}` — keyed by lowercase nickname string
- Each entry: `{ nickname: string (original case), kills: number, deaths: number, gamesPlayed: number, wins: number }`
- `winRate` is computed on read: `wins / gamesPlayed` or 0

**Methods:**
- `getPlayerStats(nickname)` — returns stats object for nickname (case-insensitive lookup via `nickname.toLowerCase()`). Returns `{ nickname, kills: 0, deaths: 0, gamesPlayed: 0, wins: 0, winRate: 0 }` if not found.
- `recordRoundResults(players, winnerId)` — takes array of `{ nickname, kills, deaths, id }` and `winnerId`. For each player: increment `kills`, `deaths`, `gamesPlayed`. If player.id === winnerId, increment `wins`. Recalculate `winRate`. Call `_save()`.
- `getLeaderboard(limit = 20)` — returns array of top players sorted by wins descending, then kills descending. Each entry includes `rank` (1-indexed). Limited to `limit` entries.
- `_load()` — reads `.db/stats.json`, parses JSON, populates `this.stats`. Handle missing/corrupt file gracefully.
- `_save()` — writes `this.stats` to `.db/stats.json` with `JSON.stringify(data, null, 2)`.
- `_ensureDir()` — ensures `.db/` directory exists.

**Export:** `module.exports = { StatsManager }`

File follows same code style as `server/roomManager.js` — section headers with `// ─── Section ───` comments.

tasks.title: Fix power-up edge cases (rapid collection, stacking)
tasks.description:
Audit and fix power-up edge cases in `server/roomManager.js`.

**Edge cases to verify/fix:**

1. **Rapid collection — double pickup:**
   In `movePlayer()`, when `curCell.item` exists, `pickupItem()` is called. If two players are on the same cell in the same tick, both could pick up the same item.
   - **Fix:** In `pickupItem()`, check if item is still in `this.items` array before applying effect. Add guard at top:
     ```javascript
     const idx = this.items.indexOf(item);
     if (idx === -1) return; // Already picked up
     ```

2. **Stacking caps:**
   Currently there are no caps on power-up stacking. Players could theoretically get unlimited bombs, range, and speed.
   - **Fix:** Add reasonable caps in `pickupItem()`:
     ```javascript
     if (item.templateId === 0) {
       player.maxBombs = Math.min(player.maxBombs + 1, 8); // cap at 8 bombs
     }
     if (item.templateId === 4) {
       player.range = Math.min(player.range + 1, 10); // cap at 10 range
     }
     if (item.templateId === 6) {
       player.speed = Math.min(player.speed + 0.1, 3.0); // cap at 3.0 speed
     }
     ```

3. **Explosion destroying items on same tick as pickup:**
   If a player picks up an item and an explosion hits the same cell in the same tick, `despawnItem()` would be called on an already-removed item.
   - **Fix:** In `explodeLine()` where `cell.item` is destroyed, add guard: `if (cell.item && this.items.indexOf(cell.item) !== -1)`

4. **Item on bomb cell:**
   `trySpawnItem()` already checks `if (cell.bomb) return;` — verify this works correctly.

**Acceptance criteria:**
- Two players on same cell cannot both collect same power-up
- Power-ups have reasonable caps (8 bombs, 10 range, 3.0 speed)
- No crashes from double-despawning items
- Existing power-up behavior otherwise unchanged
tasks.checkResult: Fixed 3 power-up edge cases in server/roomManager.js: (1) Added double-pickup guard in pickupItem() — checks items.indexOf before applying, prevents two players collecting same item in same tick. (2) Added stacking caps: maxBombs capped at 8, range at 10, speed at 3.0. (3) Added existence guards in explodeLine() and explodeBomb() center cell to prevent crashes from despawning already-removed items. Verified trySpawnItem already guards against bomb cell — no change needed.

roadmap.projectDescription: A browser-based multiplayer Bomberman-style game built with Node.js/Express, Socket.io, and HTML5 Canvas. The project is already running with core gameplay (movement, bomb placement, explosions, destructible blocks, chat). This roadmap adds player identity, competitive game loops, room systems, mobile support, and persistent stats across 5 sprints.

sprints.title: Identity, Social Foundation & Quick UX Wins
sprints.prompt: This sprint establishes player identity and fixes the most visible UX gaps in the existing game. Implement a player nickname system where players enter a custom nickname before connecting — the nickname is sent at connection time, stored on the server-side player object, and included in all subsequent broadcasts (join, movement, status). Fix chat sender attribution so messages display the actual sender's nickname instead of a hardcoded placeholder. Add a character skin selection screen shown before connecting, allowing players to preview and choose from the 24 existing character sprite sheets in the assets — the selected skin ID is transmitted at connection time and used in all appearance broadcasts. Build a full-screen loading overlay with a progress indicator that displays while game assets (map sprites, character sheets, bomb sprites) are fetched, dismissing only when all assets are ready and the world is initialized. Add a connection state overlay/toast that appears when the WebSocket connection is lost, showing reconnect status, and updating when restored or permanently failed. Finally, add a favicon, ensure the page title works across browsers, and add Open Graph meta tags (title, description, image) plus a meta description for SEO and social link previews.
features: Player nickname system with server-side storage and broadcast inclusion
Chat sender attribution fix using actual player nicknames
Character skin selection screen with preview of all 24 existing sprite sheets
Full-screen loading overlay with asset preload progress indicator
Connection state overlay with reconnect feedback on WebSocket disconnect
Favicon, page title, Open Graph meta tags, and SEO meta description
sprints.goal: Players can set a nickname and choose a character skin before joining. Chat messages show the correct sender name. A loading screen covers asset loading, connection loss is visually communicated, and the game URL produces proper link previews when shared.

sprints.title: Core Competitive Game Loop
sprints.prompt: This sprint transforms the endless sandbox into a structured competitive experience. Implement a timed round system where each round runs for a fixed duration (e.g., 3 minutes) and ends when only one player remains alive or the timer expires. At round end, broadcast a game-over event with the winner's identity, display a results screen for a few seconds, then regenerate the map and start a new round automatically. The server must manage round state (waiting, active, ended) and communicate transitions to all clients. Add a collectible power-up system where soft block destruction has a chance to drop items. Implement three power-up types: BombUp (increases max active bomb count), FireUp (increases explosion range), and SpeedUp (increases movement speed). The server spawns power-ups, broadcasts positions for client rendering, tracks per-player stats, and applies effects on pickup. Power-ups persist until collected or destroyed by explosions. Note that the variables for max bombs, bomb range, and player speed already exist as named server-side constants — modify these per-player rather than changing globals. Implement kill tracking: when a player is eliminated, attribute the kill to the bomb owner (reference already exists on the Bomb object). Broadcast kill-feed events to all clients. Display a live HUD scoreboard showing kills/deaths per player during the round, and show a round summary on the results screen. The CSS infrastructure for player statistics display already exists in the stylesheet.
features: Timed round system with win condition (last alive or timer expiry)
Round state management (waiting, active, ended) with automatic map regeneration
Results screen displayed between rounds showing winner
Power-up drops from soft blocks: BombUp, FireUp, SpeedUp
Server-side power-up spawning, broadcasting, per-player tracking, and pickup
Kill attribution to bomb owner with kill-feed broadcast
Live HUD scoreboard with kills/deaths and round-end summary
sprints.goal: The game runs in structured timed rounds with a clear winner. Destroying soft blocks can drop power-ups that increase bomb count, explosion range, or speed. Kills are tracked and attributed, a live scoreboard is visible during play, and a results summary shows at round end before the next round auto-starts.

sprints.title: Room & Lobby System + Map Variety
sprints.prompt: This sprint enables multiple concurrent game instances and adds visual variety. Implement a full room/lobby system where players can: view a lobby listing available rooms (name, player count, status), create a new named room with configurable player limit (2–8), join an existing room, and see a waiting room screen before the round starts. Each room must have completely isolated state — its own map, player list, bomb state, round timer, power-ups, and scoreboard. Add REST API endpoints under the existing /api/ route namespace for listing and creating rooms. Use Socket.io rooms or namespaces to isolate broadcasts between game instances. The HTML already contains a non-functional room button placeholder that confirms this feature was planned. Room isolation is critical: bombs in room A must never affect room B, and all game state must be fully independent per room. Additionally, implement map theme support using the three tilesets already present in the assets (default, winter, and moon themes). The active theme should be configurable per room or selected randomly at round start. Broadcast the active theme ID to clients when they join so they load the correct tileset.

Room creation with custom name and configurable player limit (2–8)
Room joining flow with waiting room screen before round start
Fully isolated per-room game state (map, players, bombs, rounds, power-ups, scores)
REST API endpoints for listing and creating rooms under /api/
Socket.io room-based broadcast isolation
Map theme rotation using existing default, winter, and moon tilesets
sprints.goal: Players can browse a lobby of available rooms, create new rooms, and join existing ones. Each room runs a fully independent game with its own map, players, bombs, rounds, and scores. Maps display one of three visual themes (default, winter, moon) per room.

sprints.title: Mobile Support, Accessibility & UX Polish
sprints.prompt: This sprint makes the game playable on mobile devices and improves overall usability and accessibility. Add a viewport meta tag for correct mobile rendering. Implement on-screen virtual D-pad and bomb button overlays for touch devices — touch events should map to the same input protocol as keyboard events so no server-side changes are needed. The overlay should only appear on touch-capable devices. Mouse event handler stubs already exist in the client events file and can be extended. Render player nickname labels above each character sprite on the game canvas, keeping them legible against varied backgrounds and updating on movement. Add explosion/death visual feedback for the local player: a brief semi-transparent red overlay flash (~300ms) and/or subtle canvas shake when caught in an explosion or killed. Cap chat history at ~100 messages with oldest removal to prevent unbounded DOM growth. Implement chat auto-scroll that shows the latest message, pausing when the user manually scrolls up and resuming when they scroll back to the bottom. The chat panel contains five filter buttons (all, text, kill-feed, mod, common) that are currently non-functional — implement the filter logic so each button toggles message category visibility, at minimum separating kill-feed from player chat. Add baseline accessibility: lang='en' on html element, role='application' on the game viewport, aria-label on the chat input textarea, aria-live='polite' on the chat message list, meaningful aria-label on canvas elements, and ensure all interactive elements are reachable and labeled.
features: Mobile viewport meta tag and responsive rendering
On-screen virtual D-pad and bomb button for touch devices
Player nickname labels rendered above character sprites on canvas
Explosion/death visual feedback (red flash overlay and/or screen shake)
Chat message cap at ~100 with oldest removal and auto-scroll behavior
Chat filter buttons implementation (all, text, kill-feed, mod, common)
Accessibility: ARIA roles, labels, lang attribute, semantic markup
sprints.goal: The game is playable on mobile with touch controls. Player names appear above sprites. Explosions and deaths have visible feedback. Chat is capped, auto-scrolls properly, and filter buttons work. All major UI elements have proper accessibility attributes.

sprints.title: Persistent Stats, Spectator Mode & Final Polish
sprints.prompt: This sprint adds persistent progression, spectator mode, and performs a comprehensive polish pass. Implement a persistent stats backend that tracks kills, deaths, games played, and win rate per player nickname across sessions. Store data server-side using a JSON file database in the .db directory. Expose REST API endpoints under /api/ for fetching an individual player's stats by nickname and for a global leaderboard. Display a player profile/stats overlay in the client — the CSS for this view is already fully defined but unused in the stylesheet. Implement spectator mode allowing players to join a room as spectators instead of active participants. Spectators receive all game state broadcasts (world state, positions, bombs, explosions) but do not spawn a character, cannot place bombs, and do not send input events. Add a 'Watch' or 'Spectate' option on the room join screen. Since the server already broadcasts all events to connected sockets, the core mechanic requires only suppressing player creation and input processing for spectator connections. Finally, conduct a full regression and polish pass: verify nickname persistence across reconnects, test power-up edge cases (rapid collection, stacking), confirm room isolation rigorously (bombs/state in one room must not affect another), test mobile touch controls on various screen sizes, verify round transitions under various player counts (0, 1, 2, max), address visual inconsistencies in HUD elements, ensure the loading screen covers all asset paths, confirm all dead UI has been implemented or removed, and fix any bugs or rough edges discovered.

REST API endpoints for individual player stats and global leaderboard
Player profile/stats overlay using existing CSS definitions
Spectator mode: join rooms as observer without spawning or sending input
Spectate option on room join screen
Full regression testing across all Sprint 1–4 features
Polish pass: fix edge cases, visual inconsistencies, dead UI cleanup
sprints.goal: Player statistics persist across sessions with a viewable profile and global leaderboard. Players can spectate rooms without participating. All features from previous sprints are regression-tested and polished, with no dead UI, no visual bugs, and stable behavior across browsers and devices.
